article.description: Jameer Nelson was perfect from the field, hitting all six attempts for 19 points, and so remains No. 3 Saint Joseph's following a 114-63 rout of St. Bonaventure on Saturday night.
article.headline: Nelson takes command early for Hawks
article.linkText: Outside onslaught leads Saint Joe's to huge win
article.story:
OLEAN, N.Y. -- Jameer Nelson was perfect from the field,
hitting all six attempts for 19 points, and so remains No. 3 Saint
Joseph's following a 114-63 rout of St. Bonaventure on Saturday
night.

	   Delonte West had 21 points, allowing the Hawks (17-0, 7-0
Atlantic-10) to set a school record with their 17th consecutive
win. Pat Carroll added 17 points in a game that was decided 8
minutes in when the Hawks scored 15 straight points to open a 20-3
lead.

	   Saint Joseph's won 16 straight from Jan. 7-March 8, 1965.

	   The Hawks, who next play Temple at the Palestra on Jan. 31,
remained one of two undefeated Division I teams in the nation,
along with No. 2 Stanford (15-0), which played Southern California
on Saturday night.

	   St. Bonaventure (6-10, 2-3) looked tight and was unable to feed
off a boisterous crowd of about 6,000, the first sellout at the
Reilly Center this season.

	   The Bonnies hit only one of their first 18 shots -- Maurice
Young's drive -- and never recovered.

	   Bonnies guard Marques Green, the A-10's leading scorer and fifth
in the nation, had a terrible game. He missed his first seven
shots, including several open looks, before hitting a 3-pointer
with 4:30 left in the first half. Green, who is averaging 24.2
points, finished 3-of-16 for 12 points.

	   Kern Carter led the Bonnies with 14 points.

	   Nelson scored all of his points in the first half, and didn't
attempt a shot in the second before he was taken out with 12:08
left and the Hawks up 79-40.

	   Nelson's performance was reminiscent of West, who last weekend
set a conference record by going 12-for-12 in an 81-73 win over
Xavier.

	   West, who went 7-for-8 in last Wednesday's win over
Massachusetts, missed his first shot against St. Bonaventure before
finishing 5-for-11.

	   As the Bonnies sputtered, the potent Hawks went to their
strength -- the potent perimeter game. Led by Nelson's four
3-pointers, Saint Joseph;s finished 17-for-26 in 3-point attempts,
including a stellar 12-for-18 in the first 20 minutes when the
Hawks opened a 62-27 lead.

	   Nelson matched his best one-half performance this season, after
scoring 19 against Duquesne on Jan. 10. And Saint Joseph's 62
points in the first half were a season high, and seven short of the
school record. The Hawks scored 69 in the second half against
Nevada-Reno on Dec. 15, 1971.

	   The Hawks offensive output was their most since scoring 116
points in a win over Wheeling Jesuit to open the 1991-92 season.
The school record is 128 against Nevada-Reno in 1971.

	   Hawks coach Phil Martelli proved to be overly sensitive in a
game in which his team was never threatened.

	   With 4 minutes left in the first half, a middle-aged female fan
behind the Saint Joseph's bench criticized Martelli for pressing
the Bonnies despite enjoying a 25-point lead.

	   Martelli snapped back, yelling, "Shut up, you nitwit." A few
seconds later he turned around again and added: "You should be
embarrassed by your own team, you moron."

	   The fan, Mary Palmer, took offense to Martelli's response.

	   "I had respect for that man until tonight," said Palmer, who's
been regularly attending Bonnies games for 18 years. "It took my
breath away when he turned and yelled at me for making an acute
observation."

	   In the second half, when Bonnies fans started chanting
"Over-rated," Martelli turned to Hawks radio announcer Tom
McCarthy and said, smiling: "They must have class here for the
legally blind."
